abstract: <jats:p>The marine ribbon worm genus <jats:italic>Tetranemertes</jats:italic> Chernyshev, 1992 currently includes three species: the type species <jats:italic>T. antonina</jats:italic> (Quatrefages, 1846) from the Mediterranean Sea, <jats:italic>T. rubrolineata</jats:italic> (Kirsteuer, 1965) from Madagascar, and <jats:italic>T. hermaphroditica</jats:italic> (Gibson, 1982) from Australia. Seven new species are described: <jats:italic>T. bifrost</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>T. ocelata</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>T. majinbuui</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, and <jats:italic>T. pastafariensis</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> from the Caribbean Sea (Panamá), and three species, <jats:italic>T. unistriata</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, <jats:italic>T. paulayi</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, and <jats:italic>T. arabica</jats:italic><jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, from the Indo-West Pacific (Japan and Oman). As a result, an amended morphological diagnosis of the genus is offered. To improve nomenclatural stability, a neotype of <jats:italic>Tetranemertes antonina</jats:italic> is designated from the Mediterranean. The newly described species, each characterized by features of external appearance and stylet apparatus, as well as by DNA-barcodes, form a well-supported clade with <jats:italic>T. antonina</jats:italic> on a molecular phylogeny of monostiliferan hoplonemerteans based on partial sequences of COI, 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, and 28S rRNA. Six of the seven newly described species, as well as <jats:italic>T. rubrolineata</jats:italic>, possess the unusual character of having a central stylet basis slightly bilobed to deeply forked posteriorly in fully grown individuals, a possible morphological synapomorphy of the genus. In addition, an undescribed species of <jats:italic>Tetranemertes</jats:italic> is reported from the Eastern Tropical Pacific (Panamá), increasing the total number of known species in the genus to eleven.</jats:p>
title: ﻿Seven new species of Tetranemertes Chernyshev, 1992 (Monostilifera, Hoplonemertea, Nemertea) from the Caribbean Sea, western Pacific, and Arabian Sea, and revision of the genus
